repnme.cdata!:
Guyana - Poverty Reduction Support Credit
            (PRSC) Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Guyana Poverty Reduction Support
            Credit (PRSC) Project was satisfactory in outcome, likely to
            be sustainable, with a modest institutional development
            impact, and Bank and Borrower performances that were
            satisfactory. The following lessons were gleaned from the
            project and used to adapt the content of the follow-on
            Poverty Reduction and Public Management Operation: 1)
            carefully setting the project's timeframe while
            considering capacity constraints; 2) donor's
            coordinating technical assistance; and 3) focusing on fewer
            areas. Also based on these lessons, the Government and the
            International Development Association agree that a series a
            series of (programmatic) development policy operations,
            timed to match the speed of Government's implementation
            performance, would be better suited to support the
            country's development needs and context.

repnme.cdata!: Guyana - Poverty Reduction Strategy Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Project ratings are as follows: Project
            outcome is satisfactory; sustainability is likely; Bank
            performance is satisfactory; and Borrower performance is
            satisfactory. Findings and implications for subsequent
            operation(s) in the series are:  1) In view of the many
            risks the implementation of this program faces, the
            timeframe of future operations should be established with
            care, taking into account possible political obstacles as
            well as capacity constraints in the public service. 2) While
            the provision of formal and informal technical assistance as
            part of the preparation of the first operation has been most
            useful, this may not be possible in future. It would
            therefore be important to ensure that such assistance can be
            provided in other ways, either through a technical
            assistance credit or PHRD grant (Policy and Human Resources
            Development Fund - Japan) or by other donors. Such
            assistance is crucial for the success of the program. 3)
            Future operations might have fewer trigger actions and
            exclude measures that are expected to be taken as part of
            other operations, whether by the International Development
            Association or other donors; 4) There are areas covered by
            the Poverty Reduction Strategy Paper, but so far not
            included in the Poverty Reducation Support Credit for
            various reasons. Subsequent operations need to take a fresh
            look at the desirability of including new components in the
            program, notably actions more focused on poverty
            alleviation, taking into account planned activities of other donors.

repnme.cdata!: Guyana - Poverty Reduction Support Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Poverty Reduction Support Credit
            (PRSC) Project is envisaged as the first, of a possible
            series of PRSCs to support the implementation of
            Guyana's Poverty Reduction Strategy (PRSP). The reforms
            supported by the project include: support for the
            implementation of a new education sector strategy; an
            expanded effort to combat HIV/AIDS; reforms in the public
            sector, covering procurement and financial management; tax
            reform, including improvements in local government tax
            administration; reforms in the water sector, including
            introduction of private management; and, restructuring of
            the sugar sector, including investments designed to lower
            costs, and restructuring and redundancy efforts, focused on
            increased productivity. Regardless of project benefits,
            risks include political factors which could divert attention
            from the reform policy, limited implementation capacity,
            limited external resources, and, a high dependency on few
            export products. However, risks will be mitigated by the
            continued Bank dialogue with the donor community, and civil
            society, focused on redressing social concerns through
            improved governance, and strengthened key institutions.

repnme.cdata!:
Guyana - Poverty Reduction Support Credit
            Project : environmental impact assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The Poverty Reduction Support Credit
            Project is the first of a series of such credits to support
            the poverty reduction strategy in Guyana. The project will
            be the Bank's principal lending instrument to Guyana
            over the next few years. The Bank is prepared to assist the
            Government with establishment of the National Protected
            Areas System (NPAS) by assisting in establishing the legal,
            regulatory, and technical framework for the system. Of the
            various PRSC-supported policy reforms, the main ones of
            environmental significance involve sugar, mining, factory,
            water and private investment. The PRSC-supported actions of
            highest environmental sensitivity involve the sugar and
            mining sectors. These actions, along with those for
            forestry, are anticipated to be conditions for the PRSC-II
            (to be processed most likely in 2004). The one of the
            PRSC-supported activities includes the construction of a new
            sugar factory along with the expansion of sugar cane
            cultivation by some 10,000 hectares. The drafting of a new
            mining law is being considered to facilitate new mining
            investments while promoting improved environmental
            management. A new Forests Act is being drafted since the
            current forestry law was enacted in 1953 and is outdated.
            The project will also support wholesale restructuring of
            Guyana's potable water supply system and the
            establishment of national drinking water quality. All of the
            policy reforms were discussed during public consultation.
